PinPress Updates with URL Linking

Sep 23, 2014
3 minute read

Last weekend, I updated PinPress – my command-line-based utility to create text templates of Pinboard data – with a (I think) much-needed feature: URL linking.

Here’s the use case: you’re humming along, saving interesting links to your Pinboard, and you want to store linkable URLs in the description of a pin1.  Moreover, you want to be able to use those links in your PinPress output: if a description includes a URL, it out to come out of a PinPress as a hyperlink.

TL;DR

PinPress now includes the ability to create hyperlinks around URLs in Pinboard data.

The Background

It seems simple enough, especially given Pinboard’s FAQ on the matter:

The only HTML element allowed in descriptions is <blockquote>, useful for displaying cited text. Any URLs in description text will be auto-hyperlinked.

Here’s the problem: although the auto-hyperlinking happens on the Pinboard website:

…nothing comparable happens to the data when returned from PinPress:

Bummer.2 It got me thinking: is there a nice way to automate the creation of hyperlinks around URLs when PinPress exports its data?

The New Stuff

Open on Github

With version 1.6.1, PinPress now has the ability to do just that. Best of all, it can accommodate two different scenarios:

  1. Auto Linking (wherein the URL gets wrapped in a hyperlink that uses the URL itself as the text)
  2. Manual Linking (wherein the URL gets wrapped in a hyperlink that uses user-defined text)

More is explained below, but make sure to check out the GitHub repository for more in-depth documentation.

Auto Linking

Auto Linking gets activated in one of two ways: either you specify the -a switch when running pinpress pins or you include auto_link: true in the pinpress section of the configuration file (located at ~/.pinpress).

Let’s try the “switch route” and run:

$ pinpress pins -n 1 -a

This produces output wherein every URL found is automatically wrapped in a hyperlink. So, for example, if PinPress finds this URL in a pin description:

http://www.google.com

…it gets turned into this:

<a href="http://www.google.com" target="_blank">http://www.google.com</a>

Neat!

Manual Linking

But what if you want to customize the text of the hyperlink? That’s where Manual Linking comes into play. Like Auto Linking, it can be activated via a switch or a configuration key/value (-l and manual_link: true, respectively).

Again, an example:

$ pinpress pins -n 1 -m

This produces a prompt for every URL, giving the user a chance to specify what the link text should be:

—> URL FOUND!
URL: http://www.google.com
TITLE: I Want to Pin Google on Pinboard
POSITION: …http://www.google.com…
What do you want the link text to say?:

Note that in addition to the URL, the user is given the title of the pin in which the URL was found and its rough “position” (i.e., where it occurs in the description compared to surrounding text).

If I type in “Le Googlez” and hit return, the URL gets output like this:

<a href="http://www.google.com" target="_blank">Le Googlez</a>

Neat again!

Saved Configurations

With both Auto and Manual Linking, PinPress saves the link information into the configuration file; under the links heading, you’ll see entries that look like this:

4a0f001e05877a9473b7dd8d3b2c70cf:
  title: I Want to Pin Google on Pinboard
  url: http://www.google.com
  link_text: Le Googlez

This happens for two reasons:

  1. By saving this configuration info, PinPress ensures that it doesn’t (a) have to recalculate hyperlinks (in the case of Auto Linking) and (b) re-prompt the user (in the case of Manual Linking) when it finds URLs in pins that it’s already run across.
  2. Going forward, if the user wants to change the URL text, they can do it easily.

Onward

PinPress is one of my favorite projects; it serves a niche need, but is super fun to play with. If there are any features you’d like to request, please do so on the GitHub Issues Page!

  1. I often like to include “via references” in a pin description: “Blah blah blah. (via http://www.whatever.com)” ↩
  2. And yet, it makes sense: Pinboard is rendering hyperlinks in its GUI, rather than modifying user data. I’d be much more bummed if it was the other way around. :) ↩
